Research

BanglaParaphrase: A synthtic Bangla Paraphrase dataset ensuring rich Diversity and Semantics

CO-Authors: Nazrin Sultana, Abhik Bhattacharya, Dr. Rifat Shahriyar

This research project was part of my undergraduate thesis where me and my thesis partner Najrin Sultana worked under Dr. Rifat Shahriyar and attempted to solve two important problems of Bangla Natural Language Processing namely: Paraphrasing and Readable Text Simplification. We successfully curated a synthetic paraphrase dataset ensuring both diversity and semantics by designing a novel dataset filtering pipeline, two of the most important criteria for a high-quality paraphrase, and developed a transformer-based paraphrase generating model and presented rigorous analysis with existing Bangla Paraphrase datasets.

Status: This work is under review in AACL

Unsupervised Bangla Text Simplification

CO-Authors: Nazrin Sultana, Dr. Rifat Shahriyar

This research project was also a part of my undergraduate thesis where we worked on Bangla Text Simplification without the need of a parallel corpus. We framed the problem of text Simplification as a style transfer problem and leveraging the parphrase generating model we developed as part of our thesis, we are attempting to simplify complex Bangla texts. As of now, The results look promising and we have identified the potential bottlenecks of the pipeline. We hope to ameliorate the performance upon further experimentations.

Status: Ongoing Research Project

Classification of variants of Corona Virus from protein sequences

Objective of this research project is to classify mutated variants of the SARS-CoV-2 virus from their primary protein sequences with the help of language models. We generated full protein sequence embeddings using pretrained proT5 model. The embeddings have been used to train a varient classifier. Currently we are leveraging existing mutation generating models to generate mutations for the varients of spike protein sequences which will be used to test the robustness of the trained classifier. We also plan to incorporate other forms of mutation generation as well as present interpretibility of our proposed models.

Status: Ongoing Research Project

CORONOSIS: Corona Prognosis via a Global Lens to Enable Efficient Policy-making Both at Global and Local Levels

CO-Authors: Ishrat Jahan Eliza,Md Hasibul Husain Hisham, Mohammad Nuwaisir Rahman, Abir Mohammad Turza, Fahim Morshed, Nazmus Sakib, Sriram Chellappan,A. B. M. Alim Al Islam

We developed an integrated dashboard as a one-stop decision support system for the covid-19 pandemic. We performed several predictions (next day predictions, when would we keep corona under control, country-wise affected and dead, etc) using customised epidemiology models. These analyses were demonstrated through interactive charts, graphs, and maps. We also explored the correlations between disease spread and diverse socio-economic and environmental factors. Furthermore, we presented how the outcomes of our work can facilitate both contemporary and future policy-making. My personally contribution to the project was by working on the Back-End part of the dashboard, integrating database and API endpoints, and ensuring security as well as optimization.

Status: Accepted as a short paper in ACM-COMPASS-2022
